title: To Kill a Mockingbird
description: A novel by Harper Lee published in 1960, which was instantly successful and has become a classic of modern American literature.
A dystopian social science fiction novel and cautionary tale, written by the English writer George Orwell.

title: Pride and Prejudice
description: A romantic novel of manners written by Jane Austen, published in 1813.

title: The Great Gatsby
description: A 1925 novel written by American author F. Scott Fitzgerald that follows a cast of characters living in the fictional towns of West Egg and East Egg on prosperous Long Island in the summer of 1922.

title: Moby-Dick
description: An 1851 novel by Herman Melville. The story tells the adventures of wandering sailor Ishmael and his voyage on the whaleship Pequod, commanded by Captain Ahab.

title: War and Peace
description: A novel by the Russian author Leo Tolstoy, first published from 1865 to 1869. It is regarded as one of Tolstoy's finest works and as one of the greatest novels ever written.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
description: A novel by J.D. Salinger, partially published in serial form in 1945â€“1946 and as a novel in 1951.

title: The Hobbit
description: A children's fantasy novel by English author J.R.R. Tolkien. It was published on 21 September 1937 to wide critical acclaim, being nominated for the Carnegie Medal and awarded a prize from the New York Herald Tribune for best juvenile fiction.

title: Fahrenheit 451
description: A dystopian novel by American writer Ray Bradbury, first published in 1953. It is regarded as one of his best works.

title: The Odyssey
description: An ancient Greek epic poem attributed to Homer. It is one of the oldest works of literature and tells the story of Odysseus' journey home after the Trojan War.
